passages.text: Weekend Chemical Reactions
What's in the Note? Click on the section title below to jump to that section:
Trending Over the Past Week What Caught Our Eye? Key Upcoming Events Weekly Recap: Key Insights from JPM Research Sector Valuation
Here, we discuss the stocks/topics where we have seen the most incremental client interest and feedback over the past week.

We reiterated Ow on Novonesis and see the the recent pullback as an attractive entry point for a stock in a league of its own (note). Investor feedback has been mixed, with HFs somewhat more cautious and some incremental interest from LOs. We have seen some inbound from a few US investors discussing a few EU chemical names (BASF, Akzo more than others) participating in the competitor conferences in the US next week.
See page 10 for analyst certification and important disclosures, including non- US analyst disclosures.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
In this section, we summarize the key newsflow and company announcements with interesting read- across for our EU Chemicals coverage universe.

- Syesnqo and to a lesser extent Victrex read: Boeing seems to be on track to ramp up production rates of 737 Max. This should likely result in very strong growth in the commercial aero business of Syesnqo (\~12% of group sales are exposed to commercial aero) and possibly also for Victrex (commercial aero around 5% of group sales) in 2026. JPM US Aerospace analyst Seth Seifman in his latest note after meeting with Boeing's CEO highlights that while Boeing is currently building 737 steadily at a 38/month rate, it is preparing to ramp up to 42/month after seeking approval by FAA, which our colleagues expect to happen later this year. Mgmt has spoken of needing to stay at 42/mo and then 47/mo for at least six months each before moving higher. Regarding its production lines, Boeing is staffed for well into the 40s. Production rate of 787 seems stable at 7/month but has potential to move up to 10/month at the existing Charleston, SC footprint. Ryanair (covered by Harry Gowers) CEO also commented during Reuters and Bloomberg interviews that Boeing has accelerated 737 Max deliveries and that Boeing has expressed confidence in raising the 737 Max production run-rate to 42/month by Oct.

- Our view: We estimate that SYENS was shipping to Boeing at a rate of low 20's shipsets per month for 737 Max. If Boeing manages to increase its production rate to 42/month in 4Q25, it may potentially drive very strong growth in SYENS's composites business in 2026. Our bottom-up model suggests that SYENS's composites business sales might be up almost 20% in 2026. The operational leverage from the likely strong growth in this business, along with expected net cost savings, might be enough to underwrite the current FY26 consensus. Thus, there is upside potential (JPME 2026E adj EBITDA is 3% above Bloomberg consensus and implies 14% organic growth) from a recovery in other end markets and incremental contribution from recent growth investments, as well as the ongoing push by management to inculcate a "hunting culture" within the sales force to win new business in its most differentiated businesses.

- IMDC announced an acquisition in Italy which should result in a 1-2% adj EPS accretion to 2026 estimates. Company has previously commented that its M&A pipeline remains strong: IMDC announced the acquisition of Tillmans in Italy, which serves the coatings, construction, food & nutrition and water treatment markets. Tillmanns also operates a logistics centre in Milan and an in-house laboratory offering advanced testing, custom formulations and technical support. It operates with 78 employees and had generated a revenue of €143m in 2024, which represents roughly 3% of 2025 JPMe revenue. The transaction is expected to close in 4Q25. Some of the suppliers listed on Tillmans website include BASF, IFF, Covestro, Lanxess, ShinEtsu, Solenis among others.

- Read across to Solvay from 2Q results/FY25 outlook of WE Soda, a key competitor of Solvay in the soda ash market. WE Soda's performance appears to be better than seen by Solvay: For the Turkish operations, WE Soda reported flat volumes and 7% YoY increase in adj EBITDA driven by a 2% YoY increase in netback price (i.e. net price after shipping costs) and lower energy costs, partially offset by slightly higher inland transportation costs and other Turkish Lira

dominated expenses. Adjusted EBITDA of \(\) 105\(per ton in 2Q25 was consistent that in 1Q25 and higher than\) \ \(96 - 97\) /ton in 1Q/2Q24. Company also noted good progress with the integration of Genesis Alkali, the largest US- based producer of natural soda ash, which it acquired in Feb 2025. WE Soda's comments on the near- term soda ash market outlook were cautious, with the company noting: "Slow economic recovery and continued geopolitical and macro- economic uncertainties still risk weaker supply- demand balances and pricing in certain markets and so we remain cautious for the remainder of the year. The longer- term outlook is, however, strong, with expected global soda ash demand growth of\) 3\% \(per annum, leading to tighter supply- demand balances in the medium term". That said, the company raised FY25 adj EBITDA guidance by \(2\%\) at the midpoint of the range, driven by higher adj EBITDA/ton guidance for the Turkish ops ( \(\sim\) 103/ton now vs. \(>\) 100/ton previously, but implies a moderation in 2H25 vs. 1H25) and stronger performance from the acquired Genesis business. Management pointed out that there is robust demand for flat glass and the battery segment is also standing out, both for EVs and mobile phones.

Our view: Solvay saw a material deterioration in the soda ash business trends, especially in the seaborne or export markets, through 2Q25 and this was one of the key drivers of its FY25 guidance cut. WE Soda's 2Q results appear to be relatively good, but due to company- specific factors. That said, we note that WE Soda's 2H25 guidance also implies some deterioration EBITDA/ton for its Turkish business in 2H25 vs. 1H25.

Slight positive read to consumer chems/ingredients and other names with relatively high exposure to the North American beauty market as Ulta Beauty (covered by Chris Horvers, note), a leading beauty retailer in the US, reported strong organic sales growth of \(+6.7\%\) YoY for FY2Q ended Jul 2025 (vs. \(+2.9\%\) YoY in 1Q) driven by traffic \(+3.7\%\) (vs. \(+0.6\%\) in 1Q) and ticket \(+2.9\%\) (vs. \(+2.3\%\) in 1Q). From a cadence perspective, growth was strongest in May and July due to timing shifts of key promo events. From a category perspective, fragrance continues to lead and was up \(+\) DD (successful Mother's/Father's Day activations, compelling newness, and strength in gift sets and men's fragrances), while skincare and wellness were \(+\) HSD (led by body care and wellness with mass/prestige skincare \(+\) LSD), makeup was \(+\) MSD (the first positive cosmetic comp since 2Q23), haircare was \(+\) MSD (led by professional haircare, accessories, and hair tools), and services was \(+\) LSD (led by cut & color). ULTA guided to flat to \(+\) LSD comps in 2H, noting a tougher comp as well as some ongoing uncertainty around consumer demand. Our view: Some of the strength in Ulta's organic sales growth was due to share gains while the category growth accelerated on the prestige side (+MSD from \(+\) LSD with mass holding at \(+\) LSD). The acceleration in category growth, which seems to be most notable in make- up, is a slight positive for companies with a relative high exposure to the North America beauty/personal care markets. These companies include: Croda, Elements, DSM- Firmenich, Clariant, Azelis, IMCD and to a lesser extent others.
Figure 1: Ulta Beauty same-store sales growth
Source: J.P.Morgan estimates, Company data.

- DSM Firmenich (DSFIR) to expand flavors capacity in India: DSFIR has announced a strategic expansion of its manufacturing operations in India, with a total investment of \(\sim \epsilon 70m\) . The company has inaugurated an expanded seasoning plant in Kerala and initiated the construction of a new taste facility in Gujarat. The Thuvaroor plant in Kerala, recognized as DSFIR's primary global hub for seasonings, will see an increase in capacity by 15,000 t/a starting October 2025. This expansion is set to enhance the company's ability to deliver customized seasoning solutions more efficiently to customers across Asia and the Middle East.
Upcoming corporate access and other events to watch

- J.P. Morgan European Chemicals CEO Speaker Series 
- Virtual, Sep-Nov 2025 
- kicks off next week with virtual sessions with the CEOs of JMAT and Air Liquide. CEOs of Air Liquide, Akzo Nobel, Azelis, BASF, Clariant, Croda, Evonik, Fuchs, IMCD, Johnson Matthey, K+S, Novonesis, Solvay, Syensqo, Umicore, Wacker Chemie and Yara confirmed so far.- 3 Sep: Solvay is hosting a sell-side meeting in London.- 16 Sep: Azelis is hosting fourth annual investor lab tour in the UK.- 17 Sep: Air Liquide is hosting a sell-side meeting in London.- 1-2 Oct: BASF CMD, Antwerp, Belgium
In this section, we aim to highlight the key JPM research reports on the EU Chemicals sector or of relevance to our sector.

- Chinese July chemical trade-flow analysis (link): There has been no major change in the trend with Chinese net export volumes, on a global basis as well as to Europe, at a record high for a number of chemicals that we track. That said, for a few chemicals, net export volumes from China to Europe were in-line with or even below the peak levels of the past three years, likely due to a combination of import duties in a few cases (e.g. titanium dioxide, vanillin, epoxy resins) and weak underlying demand. For the products we track, Chinese export/import price trends were mixed with a \(2\%\) median decline in export prices vs. Jun 2025 (MoM), despite higher naphtha (oil derivative) prices in the prior month - i.e. indicative of incremental margin pressure, with a \(8\%\) median decline vs. Jul 2024 (YoY). Overall, the data suggests that there is no change in the broader trend of continued pricing pressure from China for most product segments, due to significant industry oversupply of most of these products.

- Novonesis: Attractive entry point for a stock in a league of its own. Stay OW (link). The organic sales growth (OSG) CAGR target of 6-9% from 2025 to 2030 that Novonesis (NSISB) management presented last week remains best in class in our coverage. We are encouraged by the breadth of growth opportunities across multiple end markets, as is also reflected in at least HSD% OSG seen across all the key divisions in 1H25. The key mantra remains to stretch the core by leveraging its enviable technological edge (9%+ R&D/sales) and its ability to customize offerings (which also drives higher differentiation and pricing power) to increase penetration of its existing and new products, while also exploring growth from potential new applications/markets. This also partly explains the higher than expected capex/sales guidance of LDD% for the next three years (vs. our previous estimate of \(\sim 10\%\) ) as the company is building a platform to be able to deliver faster growth (up to \(9\%\) CAGR) than seen in the past ( \(\sim 6\%\) OSG CAGR over the past 10 years) with an underlying post-tax ROIC of \(>20\%\) . We cut our FY25-28E adj EPS by \(4 - 5\%\) , largely to reflect the incremental FX headwinds and as a result we also trim our Dec 2026 PT to DKK 512 (DKK 545). That said, with a potential \(10\% +\) adj EPS CAGR over the next 3-5 years with high underlying ROIC, we see the recent derating - FY25/26/27E P/E of \(28x / 26x / 24x\) vs. the historical long-term multiple of \(\sim 30x\) - as an attractive entry point, with our DCF model suggesting an upside potential to DKK 590.
- Weekend Chemicals Reactions: All previous editions of this publication can be accessed here.
- Givaudan: 2030 MT targets underline quality compounding, LFL 25E guided c5.5% (link). JPM EU consumer analyst Celine Pannuti highlights the 2030 strategy

outlined by the company at the Summer Conference in Zurich, targeting an ambitious organic sales growth of \(4 - 6\%\) and maintaining a \(>12\%\) FCF margin. Key growth drivers include Local & Regional (L&R) customers, Emerging Markets, and market share gains. Future focus areas include pet food, health and wellbeing, and beauty ingredients. The FCF target is supported by solid EBITDA margins, now at \(22 - 25\%\) (vs. \(22 - 24\%\) prev), though offset by higher taxes, capex now at \(4 - 5\%\) (vs. \(3 - 4\%\) prev), and less change in working capital. M&A will focus on expanding L&R customer reach and beauty and Taste & Wellbeing adjacencies. FY25 guidance aligns with consensus at \(5.5\%\) organic sales growth, despite tougher Q3 comps. The stock remains attractive at \(24x\) PE 26E, with strong H2 exit rate visibility at \(4.5\%\) .

- CEEMEA Petrochemicals Monitor: Q2 learnings from earnings: Outlook still weak but signs of anti-involution FOMO building (link). JPM CEEMEA chemicals analyst Alex Comer highlights that Q2 earnings for petrochemical stocks were weak, with conservative outlooks. Dow's CEO has highlighted a prolonged earnings downturn and unclear recovery prospects. H2 outlook remains subdued due to expected oil price declines as inventories build and slowing global GDP growth (JPM estimates \(1.5\%\) in H2 vs \(2.4\%\) in H1). Additional petrochemical capacity is expected in China, with significant ethylene capacity closures announced in Europe and South Korea. China's "anti-involution" policies may impact chemical capacities, with Sinopec potentially reducing capacity additions and shutting loss-making operations. Asian and MENA petrochemical stocks have recently rebounded, driven by investor interest in anti-involution strategies. However, uncertainty remains around the timing of capacity closures, and planned Chinese ethylene capacity additions are likely to proceed, albeit potentially phased. Fertilizer stocks, however, posted strong earnings in 2Q, supported by firm urea prices although fundamentals do not look particularly healthy given weak farm economics and high urea/crop price ratios.
Table 1: Comparative valuation on JPM estimates
Table 2: Key financials of European Chemicals companies
Source: J.P. Morgan estimates, Company data.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analyst's coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.

Coverage Universe: Udeshi, Chetan : Air Liquide (AIRP.A), Akzo Nobel (AKZO.AS), Arkema (AKE.PA), Azelis (AZE.BR), BASF SE (BASF.NE), Brenntag SE (BNR.Gn.DE), Clariant (CLN.S), Croda (CRDA.L), DSM-Firmenich (DSFIR.AS), Elementis (ELM.L), Evonik (EVK.n.DE), IMCD (IMCD.AS), Johnson Matthey (JMAT.L), Lanxess (LXSG.DE), Novonesis (NSISB.CO), Solvay (SOLB.BR), Syensqo (SYENS.BR), Synthomer Plc (SYNTS.L), Umicore (UMI.BR), Victrex (VCTX.L), Wacker Chemie (WCHG.DE)
